summary: This document is an email chain between attorney Jeffrey S. Pop and a federal prosecutor from the Southern District of New York (SDNY) regarding the potential interview of a female client (Ms. [redacted]) in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The prosecutor seeks to interview the client about logistical details and her knowledge of Epstein's associates, while Pop advocates for limiting the scope to avoid re-traumatizing her. The prosecutor reassures that the client is not considered a target and that the interview would be conducted sensitively.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pop
persons.context: Attorney representing a female client (Ms. [redacted]) who is a victim/witness in the SDNY Epstein investigation. He is communicating with federal prosecutors to arrange and scope a potential interview with his client.

persons.name: Magaly Jimenez
persons.context: Copied on an email from Jeffrey Pop to the prosecutor regarding scheduling a call about the SDNY investigation.

connections.description: Pop is the legal representative for the female client, advocating for her interests and well-being in discussions with federal prosecutors.
Professional correspondence between a defense attorney and a federal prosecutor regarding the cooperation of a witness/victim in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Proposed LA Interview Dates
events.description: The SDNY prosecutors tentatively plan to be in the Los Angeles area around February 19, 2020, to potentially conduct an in-person interview with Ms. [redacted].

events.title: Submission of Attorney Proffer
events.description: Jeffrey Pop submits a detailed attorney proffer letter to the SDNY outlining his client's involvement with Jeffrey Epstein and her status as a victim.

events.title: Prosecutor's Assurance of No Criminal Exposure
events.description: The SDNY prosecutor informs Jeffrey Pop that, based on current information, they do not believe his client has criminal exposure related to her interactions with Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: The SDNY is investigating Jeffrey Epstein and sought to interview a female victim/witness represented by attorney Jeffrey S. Pop.
The prosecutor explicitly stated the witness is not considered a target and has no criminal exposure based on her known interactions with Epstein.

The interview aims to gather information on 'logistical and atmospheric aspects,' including Epstein's comments about Ghislaine Maxwell as the 'original girl finder,' the role of another associate, and names of other girls or friends of Epstein.
The attorney is concerned about the psychological impact of an in-person interview on his client, who is described as suffering trauma to this day.
The correspondence reveals a pattern of Epstein's operation involving multiple people introducing girls to him over decades.
